fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Notes about the classic mechanics. Most of the content is based on the Wikipedia page about the subject.

The motion of a body can only be described relative to something else—other bodies, observers, or a set of spacetime coordinates. These are called frames of reference. All physical laws take their simplest form in an inertial frame. Galilean invariance or Galilean relativity states that the laws of motion are the same in all inertial frames of reference.

An increase in the kinetic energy of a rigid body is caused by an equal amount of positive work done on the body by the resultant force acting on that body. Conversely, a decrease in kinetic energy is caused by an equal amount of negative work done by the resultant force.

Work on a free (no fields), rigid (no internal degrees of freedom) body, is equal to the change in kinetic energy E_k corresponding to the linear velocity and angular velocity of that body. W = \Delta E_k

The work of forces generated by a potential function is known as potential energy and the forces are said to be conservative. Work on an object that is merely displaced in a conservative force field, without change in velocity or rotation, is equal to minus the change of potential energy E_p of the object W = -\Delta E_p

The time derivative of the work is called power: P = \frac {dW}{dt} dW can be written as the dot product of the force and the velocity of the object dW = \vec {F} \cdot d\vec {r}, hence the power can be written as: P = \vec {F} \cdot \frac {d\vec {r}}{dt} = \vec {F} \cdot \vec {v} The work then can be expressed as the integral of the power over time: W = \int _{\Delta t} P dt = \int _{\Delta t} \vec {F} \cdot \vec {v} dt
The kinetic energy of a point object, or a non-rotating rigid body depends on the mass of the body as well as its speed. E_k = \frac {1}{2} m v^2 = \frac {p^2}{2m}

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: The work done in accelerating a particle with mass m during the infinitesimal time interval dt is given by the dot product of force \vec {F} and the infinitesimal displacement d\vec {x} dW = \vec {F} \cdot d\vec {x} = \frac {d\vec {p}}{dt} \cdot \vec {v}dt = \vec {v}\cdot d\vec {p} = \vec {v} \cdot d(m\vec {v}) Applying the product rule of differentiation, we get: d(\vec {v}\cdot \vec {v}) = 2\vec {v} \cdot d\vec {v} Therefore we have: \vec {v} \cdot d(m\vec {v}) = \frac {m}{2} d(\vec {v} \cdot \vec {v}) Since this is a total differential (that is, it only depends on the final state, not how the particle got there), we can integrate it and call the result kinetic energy: E_k = \int _{v_1}^{v_2} \vec {p} \cdot d\vec {v} = \frac {1}{2} m (v_2^2-v_1^2)

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
If a rigid body Q is rotating about any line through the center of mass then it has rotational kinetic energy (E_r) which is simply the sum of the kinetic energies of its moving parts, and is thus given by: E_r = \int _Q \frac {v^2dm}{2} = \int _Q \frac {(r\omega )^2dm}{2} = \frac {\omega ^2}{2}\int _Qr^2dm = \frac {1}{2}I\omega ^2
I = \int _Qr^2dm is the moment of inertia of the body.
\omega is the angular velocity of the body.
r is the distance from the axis of rotation.

Momentum depends on the frame of reference, but in any inertial frame it is a conserved quantity, meaning that if a closed system is not affected by external forces, its total linear momentum does not change.

For a system with one or more particles, the total momentum is the sum of the momenta of the individual particles. \vec {p} = \sum m_i \vec {v}_i Or use the center of mass: \vec {p} = M \vec {V} where M is the total mass of the system and \vec {V} is the velocity of the center of mass. This formula is known as the Euler's first law of motion.

From Newton's second law, the rate of change of the momentum of a particle is equal to the instantaneous force F acting on it \vec {F} = \frac {d\vec {p}}{dt} Hence the change in momentum in time interval (t_1, t_2) can be written as: I = \Delta \vec {p} = \int _{t_1}^{t_2} \vec {F} dt = \int _{\vec {p_1}}^{\vec {p_2}} d\vec {p} We read this as the impulse I is equal to the change in momentum.
In a closed system the total momentum remains constant. A closed system means that the system is not affected by external forces. Or approximately the external forces are extremely small.

A force applied perpendicularly to a lever multiplied by its distance from the lever's fulcrum (the length of the lever arm) is its torque. \vec {\tau } = \vec {r} \times \vec {F} The magnitude of torque is \tau = rF\sin \theta (r is the magnitude of the position vector \vec {r} and \theta is the angle between the force vector and the lever arm vector).

In three-dimensional Euclidean Space, the torque can be written as the components: \vec {\tau } = \begin {pmatrix} \tau _x \\ \tau _y \\ \tau _z \end {pmatrix} = \begin {pmatrix} yF_z - zF_y \\ zF_x - xF_z \\ xF_y - yF_x \end {pmatrix} The component of torque in the direction of an axis is called the torque to that axis.
The net torque determines the rate of change of the body's angular momentum. \vec {\tau } = \frac {d\vec {L}}{dt} The angular momentum of a particle is defined as: \vec {L} = \vec {r} \times \vec {p}

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Now we prove the equivalence of definitions. \frac {d\vec {L}}{dt} = \vec {r}\times \frac {d\vec {p}}{dt} + \frac {d\vec {r}}{dt}\times \vec {p} The rate of change of linear momentum is the force and the rate of change of position is velocity. \frac {d\vec {L}}{dt} = \vec {r}\times \vec {F} + \vec {v}\times \vec {p} The cross product of \vec {p} with \vec {v} is 0 because velocity and momentum are parallel. Hence we have: \frac {d\vec {L}}{dt} = \vec {r}\times \vec {F} = \tau

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The above statement leads to the Conservation of Angular Momentum.

When a body is free to rotate around an axis, torque must be applied to change its angular momentum. The amount of torque needed to cause any given angular acceleration is proportional to the moment of inertia of the body. The moment of inertia plays the role in rotational kinetics that mass (inertia) plays in linear kinetics, both characterize the resistance of a body to changes in its motion.
